22.72.text: Who said you're supposed to survive?

27.26.text:
Who gave you the idea that it is aghast to
go on and on and on?

31.42.text: And we can't say that it's a good thing

36.04.text:
for everything to go on living for the very
simple demonstration

39.41.text:
that if we enable everybody to go on living...
we overcrowd ourselves.

46.95.text: one person who dies in a way that is honourable

51.01.text: is because he's making room for others.

56.91.text: We can also look further in to it and see...

61.10.text: that if our death could be indefinitely postponed...

68.77.text: we would not actually go on postponing it indefinitely. Because after a certain point

78.30.text: that that isn't the way in which we wanted to survive.

81.77.text: Why else would we have children?

91.49.text: arrange for us to survive in another way...

98.66.text: by as it were, passing on a torch

103.76.text:
so that you don't have to carry it all
the time.

107.43.text:
There comes a point where you can give
it up

115.18.text: It's a far more amusing arrangement for nature

118.20.text: to continue the process of life

122.01.text:
through different individuals, then it is
always with the same individuals.

126.27.text:
Because, as each new individual
approaches life,

137.30.text: the most ordinary everyday things are to a child.

141.16.text: Because they see them all as marvellous, because they see them all in a way that is

150.25.text:
When we get to thinking of everything
in terms of survival

158.93.text:
the shapes and scratches on the floor
cease to have magic

170.55.text:
So therefore in the course of nature, once
we have

173.96.text: ceased to see magic in the world anymore

177.01.text:
we're no longer fulfilling nature's game
of being aware of itself.

183.23.text: There's no point in it anymore.

185.69.text: and so we die. And so something else comes to birth

189.68.text: which gets an entirely new view.

194.93.text:
It is not therefore natural for us to
wish to prolong life indefinitely

202.23.text: but we live in a culture

205.24.text: where it has been rubbed into us

210.16.text: that to die is a terrible thing

214.50.text:
and that is a tremendous disease from
which our culture in particular suffers.
